Qasx6S1cGau6-NV89nLBfA.text: You really, really must visit the Troubadour. Originally a 1950's cafe, the place was the pulsing heart of the swinging 60's hippie music and culture scene, with the club downstairs hosting Bob Dylan, Joni Mitchell and Jimmy Hendrix to name but a few. They have an informative and interesting history section on their website that you should check out, it'll make your trip there even more special. The club is available to rent out, and still hosts live music. The crowd is very laid back, arty, hippie and generally very attractive. The food menu is sensational with burgers and steaks a plenty, but the place is most famed for its wine list. I cannot claim to know anything about wine other than i enjoy drinking it, but i am assured that their cellar is the stuff of dreams. Check their website for full details. They also have poetry evenings, and the whole place just feels magical. Since moving East i haven't been visiting here as much as i would like, and just writing about it makes me nostalgic - i know where I'm off to tonight!

KHHTb9hMZHskwELI51bg2Q.text: Bursting with character, the Troubadour Cafe is a lively fun hangout - almost an institution, it's been around since the 50s. The food's great, good quality and filling. Downstairs there's always good live music

716W269XZEE2zlCkmHUnPA.text: trendy burgers, arty things on the wall, great music including bagpipers, people reading books and drinking good wine!

4s0s0RZnXCEKQYJmPe7sbg.text: A bit hidden and a few more tube stops than anticipated but definitely noteworthy. Walking through this little pub is like taking a magical journey through Narnia's closet. The first room you enter has a plethora of old antique instruments hanging from the ceiling, which screams history. Keep walking straight through and you will uncover a tiny little garden in the back. It's ridiculously cute and compact but romantic, if that is what you desire. Come back inside though and there is another seating area, on the other side of the bar..that is a tad bit more secluded than the first. Hold on to your hats because Thursdays are hats day, apparently. One of the regular happy hour go-ers advised my friend and I that when you wear a hat, you get half-off your drinks. Not sure if that's true or not but they did come in with more than enough hats to share! With the history and compactness of this cafe, it's no wonder they have adapted a family like atmosphere. One where the servers as well as the customers are seemingly extremely close and comfortable with each other. The food isn't bad - a little overpriced for yogurt & fruits but not bad nonetheless. As for the drinks, you need to come back for happy hour. That being said, go with the Mojito. Can you say, yummy? Apparently, this place is popping when it comes to nightlife. I personally haven't had the opportunity to experience the artistic goodness but I will soon enough. FYI - they host private parties..fit enough for the Prince. Literally. I've been told that the Prince rented out the entire cafe last year. Pretty cool, huh?

8VQZHTxQNBy8KqUja9bFdw.text: I have mixed feelings about this place. Website was quite enticing and I loved the French cafe feel when I first arrived. There's a brilliant eclectic, quirky charm to the place and a bustling yet relaxed atmosphere. Table service was mostly attentive but there was quite a long wait for our orders. Price-wise, generally it's pretty expensive. £13 for a plate of buttery (slightly too oily) gnocchi with a sprinkling of parmesan is a bit much. A Martini is a whopping £10however, a huge jug of mulled wine (easily 8 glasses) is only £18 so that made up for it. The waiter even swapped the last third of it for fresh, warm stuff when he noticed it was going cold. The food definitely lets the place down. There wasn't much that appealed on the menu and not much choice anyway. They only do about 5 desserts, too of which are basic ice creams, one is a sorbet and the one most of our table wanted was Churros, which they'd run out of. So I almost gave it a 3*, but the interior design effort and effortless shabby chic of the place saved it. Would still go back there, especially to try out the music venue downstairs.

Yrsj2vllfLLvrPxoXnkuRQ.text: Great pub and concert venue. Quite crowded on fridays & saturdays  and the sound system may be a bit old or requiring better settings. But I had a nice time anyway.

ZVc2JJBoxXvN0DVqBBia0Q.text: Surprisingly good food. Low key restaurant, with character, casual staff, but simply great steak and chips. Will definitely go back.

gwAI3kVsq0TV0C_mo1Fbug.text: Nice for drinks, especially if you get a garden table. The atmosphere is lovely of an evening, however both times I've been in for weekend brunch, whilst busy, it has the air of a mortuary, and the food does nothing to lighten the mood. Coffee is bitter, service is pleasant when you can get it, but food really does leave a lot to be desired. Who serves a muffin with salmon and poached egg without offering hollandaise?? Or bacon, even when requested super crispy was still a grey-ish white and pink, chewy and too salty. Forget eating, save it for a late afternoon drink, or one of the music events and you may just enjoy this interesting venue.

82RNZJNO7mo5hdBt3MVB-g.text: Troubadour Fridays are legendary. The entire basement of the Troubadour cafe fills up from about 10pm till 2am with young, West Londoners wanting to dance to reggae,ska, and listen to new bands. The crowd is a bit annoying but the music is always amazing.The place gets packed early so we used to get there early, get dinner and have a few drinks upstairs in the cafe (which is excellent in its own right) The menu is basic but excellent- simple French bistro food- though if I am honest, we generally go for the wine list and pick at snacks.

snJpPOo13DXAFo_Yq9Plkw.text: The troubadour is a very nice cafe, restaurant with a bar and a room downstairs dedicated to music venues.I have never tested the restaurant, but I really recommend this place for music lovers, especially for rock, jazz and blues. Decorated with a huge variety of instruments and pictures from the 70s, the Troubadour hosted legendary musicians such as Jimi Hendrix, Bob Dylan and Led Zeppelin who have obviously brought a lot of charm to the place.

_VCDOSaGmLr__UH4UflJtQ.text: I have been trying to hate this place for years but cant bring myself to do it. It is all about the service. The service is really, really, really bad. It is 1970's British Rail bad. Awful. Basil Fawlty awful without the laughs. Why is this? I am not too sure, but has to be from the top down. Sultry, moody, overworked, inefficient. So why go back? Well it has a charm that is inspite of its failings. It has a shabby chic that stems from its bohemian philosopher past. Or as its website says 'The last 50s coffee house in Earls Court with a proud history as a low temperature centre of courtesy, peace and artistic energy.' The menu is predictable but works just about. The food is unambitious burgers and generous 'heart attack' breakfasts. The seating dense and generally benches and stools. Take a paper or a good book. Stop the clock. Relax and dont expect any pleasantries. Go prepared and you will just about enjoy a uniquely boho moulin rouge candles in empty wine bottles type of evening.

nd-fIezK7w7_GGceAQNr3w.text: I like the Troubadour a lot. My favourite time to go is breakfast (or brunch, though that's a lot busier): I think those meals provide the most value for money, and is when the bustling, cluttered, multi-roomed bohemian vibe works best. I'd agree that the service isn't super-fast and efficient here, but I've not found it as bad as some of the other reviewers. I wouldn't go here if I was in a rush, though. A liesurely breakfast reading the papers or a couple of drinks in the evening is the best use of the place, in my book. They have live music downstairs in the evenings, typically of the folk/coffeehouse variety (some stars of the '60s played here back in the day, I'm told). The toilets downstairs are in an interesting layout. Check out the deli next door (qype.co.uk/place/120482-…) which sells many of the dishes and ingredients they use here in the café, plus lots more.

NkFVZ08iEwol6SBemRhF0Q.text: The Troubadour is not so much a place to eat as a tradition. Its been around for many years and although its changed, the effects are rather subtle. It has a kind of slightly messy and casual look (in a good way) and can get busy with people squished into the seats and stools. I suppose that is part of the charm of a venue where you can meet a few unfussy friends for a coffee and maybe a bite to eat over a long chat. I disagree with others about service. Its just relaxed, not bad. There's also the live music area downstairs which has a similar long tradition. I'd say this place is more about soul than external appearances. Chill and Enjoy.

ZYTxVyzvGqrDKIGdZ2S7qQ.text: The Troubadour is something straight out of the 70s..kooky hippy cafe that in its day housed music from Bob Dylan and Joni Mitchell. They seem to hang on to their rich past though and it doesn't quite work anymore. The restaurant is overpriced and the food isn't very good. Staff are moody and it tends to take a while to get served. I usually come here for the music, which used to be generally always excellent. It has recently gone a bit downhill, not sure if the promoter has changed, but it used to be about quality not how trendy you are musicwise. 3 stars for a good sounding venue and rich past..

r6pnfE9xu29me3T6Na1zjw.text: The Troubador is a two headed beast - a high class Chelsea restaurant above a classic venue that has played host to the likes of Bob Dylan and Joni Mitchell back in the day... The restaurant is classy but inevitably pricey - the punters and artists who frequent the downstairs venue will rarely be found upstairs eating before the gig! However, it is worth it if you feel like pushing the boat out. The venue itself is spacious but feels intimate with the stage being located in the corner. The audience is knowledgable and gives all of the artists a chance and there is a compere on hand to keep things ticking over. As the gigs finish and the late bar continues, the room tends to fill with the trendy teens of chelsea, but the atmosphere just manages to stay on the right side of pretentious! This is a good place to know if you fancy music out west, as earls court is pretty starved of artistic outlets...

nRnN1s3oaNZHTu1e06z2MQ.text: I have to give this place a 3, just because.I walked all over west Kensington trying to find the place and when I did... they were closed because of the bloody Germans!!!OK, so it wasn't the Blitz all over again, but it was the bloody German Cockroaches!  They had to close the place as they had an 'infestation' of German Cockraoches and were dropping smoke bombs all over the place.I met the owner and his crew outside and they were very apologetic and made me really wish they were open regardless of the bug problem.They hope to be open on Monday and I will surely be visiting to say hello.I really hate roaches, they can really put a downer on your weekend :)

kArt1QBjPXC19l7RGJHBBg.text: I went here to see a few live bands perform and what I heard here was very impressive, which is why I probably enjoyed being in this bar. It wasn't too pricey for entry or drinks and I must say their wedges were absolutely terrific! There isn't too much space in the downstairs area and upstairs is fairly cramped, but this does make for a cosy, intimate atmosphere. Enjoy an effortless night out!

7Ffohe0kVq9m28U2A90cRw.text: Lots of atmosphere. Good for a drink, but food is not great and way overpriced. Worst burger I've had in a long time. How can you mess up a burger?

ku00jUABwLWXxJaDLwGbog.text: The Troubadour is the antithesis of the chain restaurantutterly unique.If Beat generation novelist William Burroughs were alive today, this would undoubtably be one of his London haunts. It's almost impossible to convey the immense character of this place. It's a moody cafe come live music venue laden with quirky features and a lived in, labrinthal feel. Maybe that's why it attracts a creative sometimes eccentric seeming clientele. Even the serving staff seem to have been shipped in from another planet. They are no pre-programmed automatons. Instead here are individuals who you can easily imagine penning a few chapters of a book, or a few bars of an opera between capuccino orders.The modern British food is reasonable and varied and the place can be busy and loud in the evenings. My tip is to visit the Troubadour solo, mid-week. Take a book, have a 3-hour coffeeand a enjoy a slice of offbeat London life.

AOqYeE3gDzFzMUfTgtFsDA.text: 5 for the friendly service and atmosphere and 1 for the over-priced  sub-standard food. Still a lovely place but it's seen better days.

exMiTxH9fOGPI7GZHI79bA.text: This is one of a kind. Run by a cheery ex-guardsman (ask for buddha) who has taken a few years to turn this back into a quality venue for food and/or drink. The change from deli to hands on wine shop next door can only help people get the best to drink. Down stairs the music is lively. Carefully chosen for variety as well as something new. When this becomes your regular you'll read the menu every time (perhaps twice) but come back to their home made burger.

FqCRGhUKTlseb7gt8XL3xQ.text: Whatever the time of day and whether you have thousands in the bank or only a few pounds, it is well worth spending a spare hour or two in The Troubadour. The Troubadour is a bar/coffee house/restaurant on Old Brompton Road, a few minutes walk from Earl's Court tube station. It is open from 9am to midnight every day. The place is decorated with a huge variety of objects ranging from stringed instruments and adverts to photos of Shackleton's 1914 expedition. Underneath the main cafe area is the Troubadour Club, a popular live music venue but I have to say I've never made the effort to enjoy what's on offer there. However, I have eaten breakfast, lunch and dinner in the cafe (not all in one day I hasten to add!) and enjoyed drinks there a number of times with friends. Although the food is not outstanding, there is a wide selection to choose from and it is good value for money. The drinks are pretty good too - it is worth noting that having been here a number of times over the years with friends and family, no one I've been with has ever complained! If you're lucky enough to have one or two friends who aren't too self conscious and easily embarrassed, you can get a free dessert on Tuesday if you wear a hat of some description. I didn't think they were serious about it but we came wearing hats one Tuesday and were treated to a delicious free dessert so it's worth a try. To be honest, my favourite thing about this place is the atmosphere. Unlike so many places in London you can come as you are, sit drinking cappucinos and reading a book and no one will push you around or try to hurry you out. It is a great place to relax and enjoy reading a novel or catching up with good friends. Check it out troubadour.co.uk

YvOLMNOS2S4J508qsiOhMg.text: Great vibe on a sunday night

FRmY_qXKEBjZSKsSjWxXVA.text: In a veritable no-mans-land of exhibit-ation, Troubadour Café is a beacon of live music, secret gardens, art, nostalgia, vintage wines, romance and stiff, stiff pours. Trust: This is the BEST kind of beacon!   Over the years, Troubadour Café has been known as everything from London's best '50s café to Jimi Hendrix's and Bob Dylan's local. But to me, this bohemian den and artists' paradise will always simply be known to me as my favourite venue on this side of London. It's perfectly formed with an amazing line up of booze, entertainment and décor. Oh, and all-day breakfast isn't anything to shake a troubadour at!

qDCqKPkolrKzKzU5wUkIJA.text: This place gets five stars for atmosphere and three stars for food, which averages out to four stars. I hear it's also great for live music, though I haven't been to see any here.The staff is great, and the atmosphere is casual and lively. The food? Decent but not amazing. You come here to hang out in a fun place with fun people.Gluten-free notes: Many of the items are naturally gluten-free.

53OWdvhFOxZ4PPE6YivQxQ.text: Nice quiet pub with a downstairs music venue, somewhat different style from your average pub. Some interesting beers available (from bottle).

CtMB6Q75qShW6dUROjSHVg.text: Always being a sucker for something a little different than an ordinary pub/restaurant, this place really is a one-of-a-kind. Quirky, yet charming and perhaps a little romantic. Starting with the very heavy wooden door at the entrance, you feel like you're stepping way back in time when you enter. The ceiling is covered in old musical instruments and the decor feels very mediaeval. The service was excellent and with it being happy hour and 2 for 1 cocktails, we weren't hard to ask! The food is very traditional English and the 'bangers'n mash' was fantastic. Great for a date night or to meet up with a small group of friends.

EPww-riRSgK_E_HRepnaeQ.text: I love this venue  it has so much character. This is (or feels like) a very old building and I love all the nooks and crannies. There is always somewhere to explore and the smoking area outside was quiet and rather pleasant with all the lovely plantsI've been to this place on 2 occasions  once for a gig downstairs and once for breakfast.The gig was superb, really lively and the space was very intimate and perfect for a small band.The beer selection was impressive with some good wholesome German beers and there was a lot of seating.I would also recommend breakfast  whist on the pricey side, it was delicious and very filling. There was also a lot of choice and I have to say, they had the best cappuccino I've had in a long time. The breakfast portion size was also very good.I thoroughly plan to go there at some point in the future for dinner. They also host a 'apartment' for 4 that can be rented and also a private room that I would defiantly look into hiring if I was holding a function.The one downside of this venue however is that in some area's it feels a little too old and run down  but I prefer this over a new build!

GZuzshC3K9seTSJHW3A3aA.text: Good food (can be a challenge to find in London consistently) with some musical history.Bob Dylan, Paul Simon, Charlie Watts, Sammy Davis jnr and Jimi Hendrix have all played here.I had no clue about this history.  I just liked some of the posts on here about it.The Decor is really cool. A ton of instruments hang from the rafters and jars of all colors sit across the windows softening the sun light coming in.The beer selection was small but adequately good.  The menu was interesting but I went with some traditional food fare.  I got the Bangers and Mash which was perfect!  My friend got a Burger which was disappointing.  However, I will not take a point off for since Britons don't take their burgers as seriously as Americans.The star off is because more beer selection would be nice and it wasn't the perfect spot.  I hold 5 stars near and dear.I will definitely come back.

U1xKA-v1Bc54ch2EryNQbw.text: The Troubadour is legendary for its live music. But what some people don't know is it has a really nice outside bit at the back. It's not very sunny but still a nice spot on a hot summer's night.

SKIcQrMEAJyoVKTw_g6vOw.text: Excellent spot for for a relaxing lunch in their garden.  Had the oddest salade nicoise ever.  Tons of tuna, no lettuce, no potatoes, on a bed of thinly sliced tomato.  Still, very pleasant spot to sit and enjoy the afternoon.

r5WpE1E-Ee4xf8fNxeXJRw.text: Sadly had a bad experience here with both wine and food. Was steered  by a very nice waiter to the house sauvignon blanc at £29 ... how could we go wrong ... it was very acidic! We both thought so. No offer of replacement! then we were served a very generous plate of grilled tasteless grilled chicken and green vegetables. Nice but pretty tasteless. I have been to the troubadour over the years many times. And it has been pretty consistent. Good food, good wine, great music. It was'nt up to its usual standards any more sadly, it was a Friday night.

iGNQMe57Qi8xvd1SWgThjQ.text: Love this place for live music, great atmosphere and pub style food. A legendary spot with great music history!

TJQQZ1hCgUjqAhkLAfPLRQ.text: I used to come here after my evening classes more than ten years ago. very happy to see that nothing has changed in the meantime - a realiable old-fashion European-style coffee house. with slow service, but then again, you certainly wouldn't choose this place if you want a quick latte on the go - Troubadour is all about taking your time, relaxing and taking in the fascinating interior. the fact that it survived for such a long time says it all - long may it continue!

8BJSrHVtSNBN9J3xM0FeUw.text: Best meatpie I had in Europe (and I tried every one I could find). Atmosphere was pretty cool, the service was horrible but I guess that's normal in Europe.

IiuLrUsV_9jx_VZA7Q0ZOg.text: I highly recommend finding a band whose music you may like and take a trip to the Troubdour. The staff was really nice and the downstairs music venue is cozy and unique.We were on a vacation to London when we recently watched The Robinsons perform - quite the treat to see a local singer/songwriter in such a unique venue.

ObX6drfFsAEzFXLmMhPOJQ.text: Cool place to hung out in the evening. Haven't had their food but love coming here for a drink and listen to live music.

Jw1EPVC5b9kXPffZ5oht7w.text: This is Unique, comparable to nowhere. Beautiful garden a great place to be in the summer with a good cocktail. Live bands, great service amazing atmosphere. Many famous bands have played here over the years and i'm sure this will continue in to the future. Has a bit of history too so get online and read up before you visit. It will make your time there even more worth while.

AOmNmSZPDHRaZuXAtLH0CA.text: The food was great.  I had the Lamb with orriciettie (sp?).  Happy hour specials are good too.  It was two for one Prims when I was there.

rNufUJw7BmSI5dXk9vkufQ.text: An original in the area. Undefeated. Have a wee sit in the lovely garden at a summers evening with a cool (German or Spanish) beer and enjoy the atmosphere. Not famous for its food but for everything else!

074gnNtwursw3IvbgEYN4w.text: Went here for a late brunch after previous plans went caput (No, I will not wait in the bright sunshine for 2 hours to get into HyperJapan, thank you very much!).  The sun was shining so we sat outside. The menu all looked fantastic, and they had Huevos rancheros, which is some big bragging right there...a non-Mexican place that has Huevos Rancheros? I'm skeptical. My friend ordered those while I ordered my go to, Eggs Royale. Now, I'm a poached egg snob. It's one of my favourite foods and I do judge places harshly if my yolk is not completely runny. In short, my friends was highly impressed with her dish and my eggs were perfect. The staff were friendly and the inside was decorated in old-time cast iron tools and skillets, which amused this old Kentucky girl. It also made me want to buy one as I need a cast iron skillet. But that's another story. I'm definitely going back to sit in the garden out back, which looked lush and shaded on a nice day.

tn8OFHQ1V4xpf5i8Wb6DhQ.text: A cool little place. I'm a fan of any venue that can incorporate live music, good food, and stiff drinks effectively.BUT I think this place has been overrun by the wrong kind of audience. I'm not being judgmental here, but on Friday night there was a very hip young beautiful crowd who had no interest in their surroundings or the awesome music coming from the basement. That's my observation. Take it or leave it.Maybe, if I gather a crowd of neat* people big enough, we could get there really early on a Friday evening so that no one else could get in! Who's with me????*By "neat", I don't mean tidy. In fact, quite the opposite.

ujQ7yZzJn1Gef7XNImnQKA.text: I wandered into The Troubadour on a Friday evening, not knowing a thing about it. Of course when I told my mother about it she replied "You know Jimi Hendrix and Bob Dylan played there, right?"We walked in and waited maybe 15 minutes to be seated in the little cafe upstairs. My boyfriend and I shared the coq au vin, which I believe was a special that night. It was absolutely delicious! One of the best meals I had in London. After dinner we wondered downstairs, bringing our drinks with us, and paid a £5 cover to get in. The room was dark and crowded but not overly so, with everyone focused on the small stage in the corner. The atmosphere was perfect, very lively and inviting. We had a few drinks and watched a couple of really great bands preform (The Huxleys in particular).I really loved this place and I highly recommend coming here should you find yourself in Earls Court!

cEUN-OaAdS8o4luuFpFhYA.text: Via West Brompton you have to pass by a cemetery to get to Troubadour which isn't really intuitive at nighttime. Once you arrive its hopping full of people imbibing alcohols of various sorts (wines and beer mostly I saw) and  eating fantastic looking, hearty meals. I just came here for a glass or two of wine. Their merlot is very light for a red wine and goes down smoothly. The atmosphere is very English home turned into a pub who wants to be a cool wine cellar. The maze to the toilets was bizarre and I'm sure more difficult once you've had a few. Next door you can buy their wines to take home.I'd definitely hang out here more often if I could.

x45VVarVnIail8cFlSSntw.text: Quirky, fun, and quintessentially cool... to me, that's what the Troubadour is all about.  I was introduced to this place by a colleague a couple of years ago and couldn't believe that after living in the UK for almost four years that I'd never been there!  When you look around and remember the names of the folks who have played in the tiny club downstairs (Dylan, Hendrix, Paul Simon, etc) the place just resonates with history.The upstairs is a very eclectic traditional coffeehouse (think Vienna in the 40s and 50s, not Starbucks) which also serves great beers and food.  There is an outstanding garden in back which reflects the age of the establishment in that it is sort of overgrown, but very cosy and comfortable -- a fabulous place to sit with friends and unwind during or after a busy day.The food is good, but not spectacular, which is the only reason I wouldn't give this place 5 stars.  With the advent of so many gastropubs in London, the standard of the food for a five star rating has risen markedly.  On a recent visit, I had the mussels, which were good, but not extraordinary.  They also have a somewhat limited, but standard selection of pub-type food (fish & chips, roast, etc).  However, this isn't a place you go purely to eat.  It's a place you go to relax and enjoy.Overall, if you're near Earls Court, you owe it to yourself to stop by this place.  It is just one of the most authentic, unpretentious cool places you can go to relax... most places have to try hard to be cool... but the Troubadour is an example of a place that looks at its history and can have the self confidence that it doesn't have to try to impress -- it's comfortable in its own skin.

L8VbaKxb9ti2rhwzTAD4qA.text: Service was bad/indifferent and added a "discretionary tip" without my consent...I would not have tipped at all with the way I was treated. Place is cool...maybe I went on the wrong day.

Av5hqTWrX3n2Qr_5D9hlFA.text: I've popped in a few times for a drink or dessert. Usually busy, thought I've always been able to find a table upstairs on week nights. Comfort and service are not really part of the experience. The staff is perfunctory but not attentive; if you need anything you'll have to flag them down.

PBtsK5og4WekyAyUlZyqgg.text: We shared a meal for two, chicken in a pot.  Excellent.  For dessert we had the toffee pudding, it was a special for the night and a great add to the menu.  After dinner we moved downstairs to the night club and saw two bands.  The first was a rock bank, Budiky.  Fantastic voice.  Then a bank that played country/blues.  Very enjoyable.  It was a great night.

z5WIoreR5M4UhCvz_Q2ZSg.text: I love, love, LOVE this place! I've gone twice for breakfast and once for lunch, and I plan to return! The atmosphere is interesting and fun, the staff are friendly, the music is a great selection (and loud enough to be heard but quiet enough not to interfere with conversation), and the food is very tasty! It's especially nice if you're a vegetarian, or someone who doesn't want to eat meat all the time. They have a bunch of vegetarian options, including a vegetarian version of the English Breakfast that is delicious... WELL worth at least one visit, if not several.

FB-rD4KSlupMgPL_UGY5_Q.text: A must go for live music and a great atmosphere. I visited here with my girlfriend and we stayed until the place closed. We had a blast.

CvbXxdYPFcwW_-IPWMwqQw.text: Really nice atmosphere with good food. Where we sat in the restaurant we were a little cramped but the service was very good and the food was very good too. Afterwards, we went into the basement for live music and drinks.

JQd4J1yVQtN_IKTl2se9LA.text: cute place for coffee, with a little bit of history included : )

eDBTsvbmpqAuCvp3AT2xCg.text: My wife and I were on vacation in England for two weeks. When we were in London we came here and had a really good time. It's a very happy, quirky place. The music playing in the restaurant was really great too. They seemed to be playing a lot of the music of famous artists who have performed there. The food was very good. I wouldn't go here for the food specifically, but the combination of good food, drink and atmosphere is well worth it. I hope we can come back sometime for dinner and then listen to the live music in the basement.Oh, and dress super hip!

YIBebyM0oQD8-GGE37nDbA.text: This review is strictly for the live music venue in the basement.  I was warned by friends that the food here is a bit overrated so after grabbing dinner at a spot down the road, my friends and I made our way to the Troubadour.  We grabbed a couple vodka sodas, made our way downstairs and paid the £10 cover.  The venue was great with some seats and folks standing and dancing to the music.  Everyone seemed to be having a great time and so did I!  The one con on the night we visited was we arrived at about 10:30 and paid a full cover for the band to stop before 12.  In the future I will make sure to arrive earlier to get my money's worth or suggest they charge less of a cover later in the evening.

tMT9iXNBdFdg3lHsGDPk_Q.text: The Troubadour is that odd mix between dive bar, boho-chic coffee house, gastropub, and grungy music venue. That's probably why I love it so much. By day, this place serves up delicious meals (upstairs) and highly rated coffee while patrons lounge in mix-matched chairs alongside antique tables. Like an English home, there are many rooms, random mini-stairs, and much more space than you would originally imagine. By night, the upstairs bar serves all sorts of drinks (their mojito isn't bad, but when there with friends we would tend towards the champagne) and dinner is served to those who are hungry.But the real fun is downstairs. A cave-like basement (no windows, very little light, concrete floors) houses a low level stage that plays host to various local, up and coming music acts. There are a few booths for sitting, a bar (necessary), a dance floor area, and a little room in the middle that houses a dude with an ipod (a DJ? perhaps...) who fills the room with sound when the bands are finished. One of my favorite nights in London was spent here, when my friends and I took over the DJing role, plugging in my iphone, and played Neon Moon while teaching the assorted English doctors, poets and grad students how to dance- country style. We drank bottles of champers (not sure who paid the bill that night- probably a new friend), gallivanted around the dance floor like the rednecks the English blokes thought us to be, and left flush with memories and giggling. Tumbling into a cab, we began planning our feast at the flat (cheesy omelets, toast with Marmite, lots of water) and our next trip to the Troubadour- our favorite place to go on a random night when we need some fun without the usual drama/lines/expense of the London club scene or the high street bar intensity. I can't wait to go back :)

k3UNDyLVkNM80UAwIi0jqA.text: Was here after watching the bronze womens volleyball match for brunch. I enjoyed the food, it wasn't bad, I had the full english, and my partner had the eggs benedict with salmon. The serving sizes aren't bad (almost approaching American style servings), but I think this place is more about quantity than quality. The coffee was good, the food just so so. We sat in the back courtyard, which was actually what gives this place 4 stars. I was about to try the Huevos Rancheros, but looking at others have it, it certainly wasn't presented very well. I mean, I've been DYING to have a great Huevos, since I've not really had them outside the US, but I don't think I was ready to try this mad looking concoction. Anyway, all in all, seemingly a great place to have a drink, food and coffee in the area,but I wouldn't travel across London to Earls Court for it. 4*s because of the ambience, 3 for the food.

LUg8IXYvVZU9DT3zYmbgfA.text: Giddy schoolgirl omg, omg, omg!!!!LOVE the Troubadour! The cocktails, the crowd mix, the music, the decor, the history, the coq au vin!!!Go! Now!

lJpu5z2pGQeFHGVbP3yxUQ.text: Troubadour is a really strange place -- I went by thinking I could pick up some antique hand-tools, but soon realized they sell alcohol rather than shlock.  Thankfully, I didn't actually want to buy old crap, and very much wanted to drink until I was overflowing with Czech beer.And overflow I did. The service is fast and friendly, the beer is great, and the atmosphere is very cool; its a far cry from most of the bars in Kensington & Chelsea which tend to be either overly shi-shi, shit, or both!I used to go ages ago and completely forgot about it, but have recently revisited the old Troubadour and found it hasn't changed at all; a good thing when bars in London tend to last only a few years!Dunno ab food or whatever, but always looks good walking by.

W_P0ifim-ar8C1h_VBAQKQ.text: Needed a mid morning brunch while killing time and thought we'd stop in here. And oh wow - Hendrix played here! On top of that, we had the BEST mocha ever and the world's most enormous omlette.  The outside garden was incredible and service fantastic.  Can't say enough good things.

b_Qhlx0vvRr85Uxime5vjQ.text: The Troubadour is a great favourite with many of my friends (gay ones especially), but I must confess that I've never really got it. It's improved markedly thanks to the smoking ban, but it is still incredibly crowded - the tables and chairs really are packed in - and the service is legendarily bad. The food is also variable: my advice is to stick to their breakfasts, omelettes and burgers - which are both cheaper and better than trying more fancy Italian-inspired dishes. Their wine is expensive for what you get, too. In effect, you are much better off treating it as a coffee house for breakfast or lunch than as a restaurant for dinner. So why go at all? Well, there's no denying that it has atmosphere - if you are ever going to meet Left-Bank style intellectuals, it'll be here. On some nights, you could almost imagine Piaf walking through the door. When so many other venues are just tacky or lifeless chains, it really does deserve the term 'institution'. Just be prepared for slow service, and don't go if you are claustrophobic

photos.caption: Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom. The Troubadour, Delicatessen and Restaurant-Cafe

rJ4iYgJoewm0bJCU7pfw8w.text: I live around the corner so I'm a regular here. Amex have had some good offers  on money off in the past here - I wish we'ld get more! Firstly I've been here many times for Sunday breakfast - absolutely lovely. I recommend the omelettes and the fisherman's breakfast. Obviously a tad expensive but considering the area and the service, it's worth it. There is a lovely outside garden too.For dinner, I ordered the fish and chips - good quality pub food I would say! It's always crowded so service can be a bit slow at times. This is also one of the few pubs I'm comfortable ordering wine. Wine is pretty good and I believe it's probably cos of the associate wine shop next door.I've also been for a gig here (in the basement). I would say this was my only bad experience - really tiny space and way too many drunks. I was surprised to later find out that some of the drunks were part of the band performing (some Texan family band!) Considering many indie bands were discovered here, I may give it another chance.

_AjD2oSvYjWitAiYvjRNng.text: Ambience and service were lovely!  We sat in the garden in the back for lunch and had the whole place to ourselves.  We ordered some cocktails and, being that this was our first meal in London, the fish and chips.  The cocktails were well priced and generous.  The fish and chips were OK  but according to other reviews, they have other dishes that are much better and probably less touristy.  I would have loved to see live music here!  The decor at this place is awesome.

AAmmEMX8hgpyt-pDVWLWNw.text: The best part of this review was when I referred to a waitress as a "passing topknot".  Lol.  That still makes me laugh.

photos.caption: Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom. Always appreciated when a large glass of wine is, in fact, large. Like half a bottle large.

XvDkkCVWR-9MaCeoV4pHow.text: The owner of the hostel recommended this location to us for breakfast and we are glad she did! It's got a ton of personality-the aesthetic isn't for everyone-but we surely enjoyed it. I got the vegetarian breakfast and was not disappointed. Great service and great food

ej87-Fg9TGzFK4RfazK3Pg.text: Went in here for breakfast and they treated us pretty good. Not the friendliest staff but they were pretty decent by allowing us to take pictures and showing us to the small club in the basement where all the classic musicians played. There's about 4 rooms to eat in this place and they all are unique. Very cool.We ordered avocado toast and the full breakfast. It's was all cooked well and very tasty. You can't just get bacon and eggs but the full breakfast was good nonetheless.

photos.caption: Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom

Wpr-YRkABakAEK6sTZMQiQ.text: 6/17/16James & I met Sadie here for beverages & appetizers. We had the Charateurice with varioussausages, meat, pickles & bread.I had the Chelsa Blonde which was quite good.Jimi Hendrix & Bob Dylan played here.

photos.caption: Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom. Nice appys!
Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom. Hello Chelsea, 6/18/16

pJ86g3nN8f3apD0mlaYXeg.text: The Good:  :: ambiance!  :: charming pub  :: lots of seating  :: outdoor seatingThe Bad:  :: there's nothing bad, there's just...The Ugly:  :: service. it is horrible. it took almost 20 min for me to get someone to take my order. the server had come by first when i sat down, then he disappeared for a while and i finally had to flag down another server to take my order. food took FOREVER (over 30 minutes) to come out. i didn't realize it took that long to whip up rocket and parmesan. had to chase down a server again to get my bill. i wasn't the only one frustrated with the service: a couple sitting next to me with a dog was getting annoyed at waiting a long time to get their glass of wine and some other things. the woman had to chase down a server to get some attention.Would I go back? Only if I'm not in a rush or am just enjoying a drink. Too many other pubs and restaurants in London that I can get better service from that won't make me chase down a server.This place is IN (but only conditionally).

bn5DwGCUzA8IyOCabGE6Aw.text: Came here with my mom and brother a couple of weeks ago on a Monday night while on vacation after seeing great reviews on Yelp. We arrived 5 minutes before happy hour ended, which we knew nothing about! We ended up with 2 for 1 drinks so immediately happy campers. The decor was really cool and we sat in a booth also known as Satan's Gate. Our waiter was super friendly. We all had fish and chips, which was excellent and finished dinner with sticky toffee for dessert. I would slap someone to get it again - SO GOOD! Check this place out!

photos.caption: Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom. Fish n chips
Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom. Decor
Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom. Decor

qFvgZctQVrXgxQ5wPBr_-A.text: Went for brunch and would need to go back to try diner menu. Great chill place for brunch though. Classic brunch things on menus, good beers and staff. Though like always a brunch does not really show the true face of the place, don't you think? Will need to go back.

4eM3h4GjTAxgezRyELR8hw.text: I've heard a lot about the Troubadour and glad I finally got around to visiting this place.  Highly recommend making reservations in advance as it gets quite busy. We were initially planning to just have drinks and ended up having dinner there.  The place is great for drinks - relaxed almost quirky atmosphere and a good range of selection of cocktails as well as beer and wine.  Really like it!Dinner is more of a 3 star affair - tables are way too small to have enough space for all of the plates if everyone orders a dish.  I ordered the veggie burger with sweet potato fries and it was just okay.  A little bit on the underwhelming side.  My bf ordered the beef stew which was okay but still probably not the best dinner choice - but pre or post dinner drinks!

m36LeBkHNv7-5gZDZM7dFg.text: A friend suggested live music for Friday night entertainment and we ended up heading to The Troubadour. Our plan was simple: chat over a glass of wine and then head downstairs for some live music. However a few things didn't go as smoothly as we hoped:1. Finding a table. I walked in and was told that there's no table available currently. The waitress didn't tell me if I should wait inside or outside or don't even bother to wait, so I ended up standing awkwardly at one end of this crowded cafe waiting for someone else to rescue me. Luckily a table opened up shortly and I claimed it with lightning speed. 2. Slow service. We just wanted to get a glass of wine, but it took 15 minutes to get a menu. The large glass of red wine is indeed very large (I'm pretty sure I was more than tipsy when I finished it). I forgot what kind of wine we got because my French friend was in charge, and he told me it wasn't good. So I took his word for it. 3. The bands. I think we just went on a very unfortunate evening and the bands were not good. First there was a very cheesy English pop band that performed some nice song but the vocalist wasn't that good at singing. Then a French band came to perform dancy/clubby music (in English), and that was horrendous. The vocalist kept trying to get everyone to dance or clap their hands, and mumbled something like "it's all about clubbing~"... SO AWKWARD. We sat through 2 songs out of politeness and then fled... 4. The live music ticket was cash only.I would probably give this place a 2nd chance but I'd check the genre of the bands before coming (and bring cash!).

589rbP959S0FkGkFlDPCIw.text: My husband and I were traveling from the States and found this place on Yelp while we were out exploring for the day.We came for dinner, but if we lived in town we would definitely enjoy the live music here in the basement. It seemed cozy and intimate and a really cool place to see a band play.Dinner was really good, though not earth shatteringly so. He had fish and chips, I had salmon, and we washed everything down with a few pints. Everything tasted fresh and yummy. The coolest part of this restaurant is the ambience -cozy, dimly lit, and lots of cool decor to look at. Overall a great atmosphere for dinner!

iWQ6REYZeLCqHFN_oAvAqA.text: The Troubadour is what I think of when I think of an English pub. It's unpretentious, cozy and leaves you happy and full. We dined here twice while  visiting from the states because we loved the food and atmosphere. My favorite dish was the hen egg on a tortilla with avocado salsa. We have to make it back for a concert!

AFT45Og67tXln1weCUuQxQ.text: Came for dinner with a friend and thank goodness they introduced me to this place! Friendly service, tasty food and we were lucky enough to just catch the happy hour with two for one cocktails - our old fashioneds were POTENT!! But perfect when the ice melted a little :)I made the mistake of having the SPICIEST meal (huevos rancheros) but wowzers was it tasty! it looked pretty cool too - very green - but I forgot to take a picture because first I was too hungry, and then I couldn't concentrate because I was suffering from 'spicy-mouth' haha.My dining companion had the lamb burger on ciabatta and it was amazing. He was foodgasming all over the place - I tried some and it really was delicious!Great atmosphere, and I will definitely be back to check out a music show downstairs as I hear they don't ever have a dud!! And in the summer there's a lovely little beer garden.

rZRFTPdgB2wHxhYeq94mSw.text: Delicious food and excellent service! Was looking for a spot to have breakfast or brunch and stumbled upon this gem. We were definitely not disappointed!  The feel is eclectic and the music streaming through the restaurant adds to the unique ambiance. We enjoyed eggs royale, eggs florentine with bacon and enjoyed the French toast as dessert. The food was amazing, even tempted to return for dinner!  A must visit if staying in this area.

photos.caption: Photo of The Troubadour - London, United Kingdom. A perfect latte

VBjKigKVPqdxsosz3ys8ig.text: My favourite live music joint in London.  They always bring in the best artists.  I love the small dark club with the most perfect acoustics.  I always feel like I'm in someone's home listening to friends play.  Their drinks are pricey, but they have a 2-4-1 deal at the beginning of all shows (and they are strong!) This place is truely a treasure - if you haven't been...go! And it's worth buying advance tickets online.  It always fills up and you save a bit of money.

58nrd3mpk_cLXDVpQjg9Og.text: This place is my favourite London pub! Friendly, welcoming staff, great menu and lots of tasty craft beer. Try and reserve a table outside during the summer months.

M53DKWpCiDSo-BrZ0x2vrw.text: I'm actually a fan of the Troubadour because of its fantastic decortions, great ambience, dreamy back garden, and cool concerts downstairs. But I can't praise the food unfortunately. The sweet potato fries are yummy but they don't really count. I've tried a disappointing veggie lasagna, a mediocre veggie sausage and mash, an ok veggie burger, and a rediculous raw veggie platter. Maybe they're better at meaty dishes but that doesn't make up for it.Anyways, the drinks are good and the place is just so cool that I'll defenitely go again and again - just maybe not for a big meal.

_5CTKlOZfV6wJ7vBKi3Dyw.text: I stopped by for dinner, it didn't seem too crowded and had gotten above-average reviews from fellow Yelpers.  However, sadly, I was a bit disappointed:     * Fish and chips were very greasy.  Dripping with grease.  Small portion of fish too.       * Only one waiter for the front area, he was nice but totally overwhelmed.  Thus, what should have been a quick dinner turned into a 75 minute project.       * Smokers stood at the front foor-- and since the front door was propped open to let in the "fresh" air, I choked in cigarette smoke all through dinner.     * Dessert was outstanding.

uyvK_LjQ7jXDylcip9xIFw.text: AMERICAN PERSPECTIVE: I love this place. If you like live music for cheap and hole-in-the-wall atmosphere, The Troubadour is awesome! The drinks are a bit pricey, which sucks for the student budget, but I love live music from unknown artists and they always have little concerts in their basement. It gets a little crowded, but always great bands playing!

vBfZPDSM8bRBQ-kX1p7xUw.text: Having grown up in Earls Court,I wish I went to this place more often and it is only within the last few years that I have spent any considerable time here. You can pretty much find something in the Troubadour for any occasion at any time in the day... Breakfast, lunch, dinner, drinks, club and live music!! Lots to choose from and a good experience at many of these times will bring you back for more. There is an excellent menu available all hours of the day, some good vegetarian options too and they always welcome mixing and matching. Whilst the upstairs restaurant does get busy on a weekend (and they do recommend booking) the staff, who are very welcoming and friendly, if a little scatty at times, will do their utmost to accommodate you, even if it is in the wine bar next door. The atmosphere is always warm and welcoming and the decor is full of music memorabilia, local area history and artefacts! Do not be afraid of getting cosy if it is busy but the hubbub will def add to your experience. If you are up for a night of live music and or music (?!) the downstairs club is worth a visit and you may well be lucky enough to catch a guitar legend on a rare occasion. The booze runs and the music plays and your evening will be enjoyed by all! Price wise, food is good for the price but not cheap. £10-£13 for a main but your plate will be piled high and well worth it. Drinks again vary in price depending what you want but I genuinely have a really nice time wherever I am in the building and I would recommend it to anyone.Xyz

0M4ghE7WBmb4g4a4rfwYIw.text: So...if you gave this place a 3, I could get it.When my friends told me about a place for live music, I was interested. We grabbed a drink upstairs, no food, and it was definitely a bit quirky decoration wise. Beers were a little above average price but the vodka drinks were a good deal (though service hiked it up).The live music comes with a charge of £10 per person. Not a terrible deal for live music BUT we heard one song and then they were done. Our entire group definitely felt a bit cheated...The place was packed for that one song (and presumably for the entire set). And gee it's hot down there.. There is a £10 credit card minimum also. Unlike in the US where they keep a tab open for you (I just moved from there), the bartender told me to pay then for two beers, only take one beer, and come back later for the second beer. Slightly interesting.My friend was approached by a man who looked 70 years old and asked her for blow (seriously). But then we also met some guys more our age who were quite friendly.I'll be back. But next time I'll go earlier than 10:15 to ensure I get my £10 worth of music. Maybe I'll even find out how to reserve a table downstairs!

ypu_hVEZtgn_AduKhOTiDg.text: It was a very nice surprise at dinner time. Even with a 4-year old daughter we found this to be very warm and enjoyable to pass some time. The angus steak was very good, the music was even better. Will come back, for sure.
